reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s claim (especially in §3.2) that under linear/unbounded views, value-per-resource is likely fat-tailed enough that only very specific uses capture most attainable value. This is a meaningful support for the broader “fussy views / narrow target” conclusion, but it is not the whole case (the essay also argues from multiplicative fragility, population ethics, digital welfare, bounded-view sensitivity to bads, etc.), so centrality is moderate. The critique’s substantive point—analogies to wealth/citations don’t by themselves justify a fat-tailed moral value-efficiency distribution, and the extrapolation to future value is under-argued—does weaken that subargument, but it doesn’t decisively refute it (the position offers additional motivations like extreme experience tails and structural considerations about searching a vast space of configurations). The critique is mostly correct, clear, and focused, with little dead weight, but overall it poses only a limited problem for the position rather than a major one.
title: Fat-tailed value distribution is assumed without adequate justification
